questions.question: Heme is derived from which of the following amino acids?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Glycine Explanation Glycine combines with succinyl-CoA in the first step of heme synthesis , catalyzed by the enzyme δ -aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthase . This reaction is the rate-limiting step in heme biosynthesis. Glutamine (Option A): Glutamine is involved in nucleotide biosynthesis and ammonia transport but does not play a direct role in heme synthesis. Glutamate (Option C): Glutamate is primarily involved in the synthesis of glutathione and neurotransmitters but does not contribute to heme synthesis. Valine (Option D): Valine is a branched-chain amino acid involved in protein synthesis and energy production but not in heme biosynthesis. Reference: Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry Edition 7th Pg. 271, 272, 273

questions.question: Which of the following amino acids are necessary for purine ring formation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Glycine, Aspartate, Glutamine Explanation Purine ring formation requires three amino acids - Glycine, Aspartate, Glutamine and the cofactor N10-formyl tetrahydrofolate (N10- formyl THF) for purine ring formation. (Option B) (Option A, C and D ruled out) The sources of each atom in a purine were found by feeding isotopic precursors of uric acid to pigeons. The C-2 atom is from formyl THF The C-8 atom is from N5N10 methenyl THF The C-6 atom is from respiratory CO2 . N1 is from aspartate N3 and N9 are from Glutamine C4, C5 and N7 are from Glycine Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7869020/ Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd edition, pg:338, 339 Vasudevan textbook of biochemistry, 7th edition, pg: 208

questions.question: Decreased % transferrin saturation is seen in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Iron deficiency anemia Explanation: Laboratory findings in iron deficiency anemia: Hemoglobin Indices Low Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH), Low Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) Peripheral Blood Smear Microcytosis, Hypochromia, Anisocytosis Serum Ferritin Decreased Serum Iron Decreased Transferrin Saturation Decreased Total Iron-Binding Capacity Increased Stool for Occult Blood May be positive Mentzer Index >15 Hemoglobin Electrophoresis Normal Bone Marrow Aspiration/Biopsy Iron stores absent on staining In the rest of the conditions, the % transferrin saturation is normal or increased Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448065/

questions.question: Which part of the haemoglobin molecule does 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) bind to in order to regulate oxygen release?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Beta chains of haemoglobin Explanation: 2,3-BPG binds within the central cavity of the deoxyhaemoglobin tetramer . It interacts with positively charged residues (mainly lysine and histidine ) on the β -chains . This binding stabilises the T (tense) state , lowering haemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen and promoting oxygen delivery to tissues. Effect of 2,3 BPG on Hb: Reduces the affinity of Hb for oxygen and helps unload oxygen to tissues. A by-product of glycolysis. (Rapaport Leubering Cycle) Alpha chains of haemoglobin (Option A) : Incorrect because 2,3-BPG binds primarily to residues on the β -chains , not the α -chains. Heme iron centre (Option B) : 2,3-BPG does not bind directly to heme or iron ; it acts allosterically , not at the active oxygen-binding site. Globin-heme interface (Option D) : This is the site of coordination between globin and heme, not where 2,3-BPG binds. Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 55

questions.question: What does iron deficiency anemia (IDA) stand for?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Laboratory findings in iron deficiency anemia: Hemoglobin Indices Low Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH), Low Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) Peripheral Blood Smear Microcytosis, Hypochromia, Anisocytosis Serum Ferritin Decreased Serum Iron Decreased Transferrin Saturation Decreased Total Iron-Binding Capacity Increased Stool for Occult Blood May be positive Mentzer Index >15 Hemoglobin Electrophoresis Normal Bone Marrow Aspiration/Biopsy Iron stores absent on staining Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448065/

questions.question: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis pathway? B. δ Amino-Levulinic Acid dehydratase C. δ Amino-Levulinic Acid synthase
questions.explanation: δ Amino-Levulinic Acid synthase δ Amino-Levulinic Acid synthase (ALA Synthase) Explanation: This enzyme catalyzes the formation of ALA from glycine and succinyl-CoA. It is the rate-limiting enzyme of the heme synthesis pathway. Its activity is tightly regulated by feedback inhibition by heme itself. Heme Synthesis: Step Reaction Enzyme Location Key Points 1 Succinyl CoA + Glycine → Delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) ALA Synthase (Option C) Mitochondria Rate-limiting step ; requires pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor 2 2 ALA → Porphobilinogen (PBG) ALA Dehydratase (Option B) Cytoplasm It involves removal of 2 molecules of water; the enzyme contains zinc and is inhibited by lead 3 4 PBG → Hydroxymethylbilane (HMB) Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase/ HMB synthase (Option A) Cytoplasm - 4a HMB → Uroporphyrinogen I Spontaneous cyclization Cytoplasm - 4b HMB → Uroporphyrinogen III Uroporphyrinogen III Synthase Cytoplasm - 5 Uroporphyrinogen III → Coproporphyrinogen III Uroporphyrinogen Decarboxylase Cytoplasm Decarboxylation, removal of 4 molecules of CO2 6 Coproporphyrinogen III → Protoporphyrinogen III Coproporphyrinogen Oxidase Mitochondria 7 Protoporphyrinogen III → Protoporphyrin III Protoporphyrinogen Oxidase Mitochondria 8 Protoporphyrin III → Heme Ferrochelatase (Option D) Mitochondria Insertion of Fe2+ Reference: Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry Edition 7th Pg. 271, 272, 273

questions.question: A female was diagnosed with lead poisoning. What is the probable enzyme defect responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation: inhibiting 3 enzymes of the heme synthesis pathway: Enzyme inhibited Features ALA dehydratase (Primarily inhibited) ALA elevation Coproporphyrinogen oxidase Coproporphyrin elevation Ferrochelatase Elevated Zinc protoporphyrin levels (Most sensitive marker) ALA synthase (Option A) is an enzyme involved in the first step of heme synthesis, where delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) is formed. Heme synthase (Option C) , also known as ferrochelatase, is involved in the final step of heme synthesis, where ferrous iron is inserted into protoporphyrin IX to form heme. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase (Option D) is an enzyme involved in the conversion of coproporphyrinogen III to protoporphyrinogen IX in the heme synthesis pathway Reference: Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry Edition 7th Pg. 276
